smell_analysis.justification: Reviewed the diagrams across pages 1-19; each page that is labeled as a specific diagram type contains visible elements, so no empty diagram was found.

The use case diagrams on pages 2 and 3 list actors and use cases; there is no explicit, unambiguous evidence that any visual oval use case lacks association with an actor based on the visible extracted content.

Across the use case diagrams (pages 2 and 3), the use case names appear to describe different activities (e.g., viewing active vs all cars, registering vs ending a car). No clear pair of same-activity use cases associated with the same actor is explicitly visible.

The package-related overview on page 1 does not clearly show multiple distinct model elements with the same primary name in the same package. Repeated texts such as 'Klassifikaatori tüüp' on page 7 appear to be classifier-type metadata and are excluded from this rule by the clarification.

Database diagrams on pages 14-19 show standard columns and foreign key structures; there is no explicit evidence that the same data value is redundantly stored across tables without a foreign key connection.
Use case names on pages 2 and 3 appear consistently verb-led (e.g., 'Tuvasta', 'Vaata', 'Registreeri', 'Lõpeta', 'Muuda', 'Aktiveeri', 'Unusta'), so no inconsistent form is visible.
The state diagram on page 9 lists multiple states (Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Lõpetatud, Ootel, Unustatud) with an initial node; no state is explicitly shown as unreachable in the visible information.
The activity diagram on page 4 shows a start, actions, decisions, and an end; no action is explicitly indicated as unreachable based on what is visible.

Class diagrams (e.g., pages 5, 6, 10-13) show multiplicities such as '1' and '0..*' near relationships. Database diagrams rely on standard FK connectors and annotations (pages 14-19), which are exempt under the interpretation rules. No clear UML-style relationship lacking multiplicity at both ends is explicitly visible.

Use case diagrams on pages 2 and 3 appear to contain fewer than 10 use cases. The major class/database diagrams shown (e.g., pages 14-19) also appear to display fewer than 10 central tables per diagram, and the overview on page 1 is excluded from counting. No diagram clearly meets the 10-or-more threshold.

No single class/table is unambiguously shown with six or more distinct visible relationship lines on a single diagram based on the extracted content. Lists of FK/constraint names (e.g., pages 14, 17, 18, 19) are textual annotations and do not count as separate drawn lines per the counting rules.

The rule requires a visual distance comparison; the extracted content does not provide explicit spatial measurements or clear evidence of unusually distant related elements. Therefore no violation can be asserted.

Use case names on pages 2 and 3 start with active verbs. In the activity diagram on page 4, labels beginning with 'Kas' appear to be decision questions rather than action names; no activity action is clearly shown with a non-verb start.
No class, table, attribute, or use case name with 3 or fewer characters is clearly visible in the diagrams (e.g., 'Auto', 'Isik', 'Klient', 'Riik', and longer attribute/column names).

Entity class names visible in class diagrams appear capitalized and singular (e.g., Isik, Töötaja, Auto, Klient, Klassifikaator). Plural register-style names like 'Isikute register' or 'Autode register' are exempt per the interpretation rules.

In the class diagrams for the classifier registers on pages 7 and 8, the attributes of 'Klassifikaator' include names starting with uppercase letters such as 'Nimetus', 'On_aktiivne', and 'Kood', which directly violates the rule.

Database table names shown in the database diagrams (pages 14-19) appear singular (e.g., Isik, Kasutajakonto, Auto, Riik, Auto_mark). No plural table name representing an individual entity is explicitly visible.

No class, table, attribute, or use case name visibly uses a disallowed type-indicating prefix such as 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'str'. Allowed prefixes like PK_, FK_, pfK_, and IXFK_ appear in constraint/index annotations in the database diagrams.
